text: I got a story to tell.
A yarn about cow country and cow punchers.
Cattle and men.

I was working for the Strobie Ranch
learning my trade.

Trade of worn leather,
saddle blisters and branding irons.

Trade with some song,
some fun and some luck.

It was as good a job
as a man could ask for.
Lonely, sometimes cold.

So much distance,
you thought you'd never get back,

but for me, a young kid,
it was a fine time.
Memories are mostly good.

You're up there on top of the world,
where the air was clear and thin.
The only sound was the wind in the pines.
We were in the business of growing beef.

Always moving the cattle
and looking for new feed.
They were those new bald-faced heifers.

Not like the longhorns,
wild and spooky but friendly critters.
Gentle as a dog.
Seasons melted away peacefully
from spring to summer, fall, then winter.

Cows had to look out
for themselves in the snow.
The winter drift.

Soon as a man on horseback
could get around,
they'd go out and locate the cattle.
Spot them for the spring roundup.

They'd come back
from the winter drift cold and worn out.
Our foreman was Owen Daybright.
He knew what he was doing.
We all liked him.
There was his foster brother Lee Strobie.
Their father owned the ranch.

The night they got back,
the trouble began.
Well, look what's turned up.
Hiya, Cal.
People still drink whiskey.

-Hiya, Lee.
-Beat down to my shoes.

That's what comes from working for someone
you've known too long, Lee.
Seen my wife this winter?

Jen comes into town
a couple of times with your old man.
How'd Arch look?

Oh, just fair, I'd say.
Cold weather always seems to bother him.
How'd Jen look?

The way to find that out
is go home and see for yourself.

-Yes.
-Can I borrow your razor, Cal?

-I don't want to scare her.
-In the back.

-Keeping you busy, Doc?
-A night doesn't go by…
They've been trying to get him all-day

for that girl who used to work
at the Eaton house.
Lily?
I wouldn't know her name.
What's her trouble, Doc?
Oh, small variety.
About that big.

Arrived a couple of hours ago,
they tell me.

-You wouldn't go?
-That's right.

I don't take calls like this
until I hear from the father,
and that isn't likely.
There's a rifle on you, cowboy.

Get down and walk over here
so I can see who you are.
Get down now!

-Owen, is that you?
-Yes.
Put that gun down.
He's a friend.

-What are you doing here?
-Helping.
Nobody else would come.
So I heard.
How's Lee?
He wants to see you.
I'll be home as soon as she's asleep.
Who's he?
Her brother Dick Fasken from out of town.
He spent the day looking for the man.
Is Lily all right?
You've got company, Lily.

-Hello, Owen.
-Lily.
Pen size.
And beautiful.
Good color, too.
Yes.
The doctor wouldn't come.
Jen came instead.
Don't even think about it, Lily.
Not now.
I'm really pretty lucky, Owen.

I couldn't face up
going back to the restaurant to work.

Mrs. Burke offered us work
at her place when I'm ready for it.
We're grateful, too.

It sounds queer to say it here and now,
but he'll have a good life, Owen.
I'm sure he will, Lily.
I'm sure he will.
Coffee?
Thanks.
You've seen me before, Owen.
There's been a change.

Somebody washed your face
and got you a new dress.
Arch, and a tub in my own room.
I bathe every day now.
It's an improvement.
How was the winter?

Well, we stayed alive,
and we kept the cattle alive.
It was snowing at the ranch.

I didn't see our nearest neighbor
in nearly five weeks.
We missed you, Owen.
I brought Lily some grub.
Owen…
Who was it?
Goodnight, Jen.
Hold it a minute.

-Do you live in these parts?
-Around here.
Who's the father?
That'd be Lily's business.

-I'll find out.
-Sure.

-I'll find out if it takes me a lifetime.
-Fine.
It's a nice country to live in.
Who was that?
Owen Daybright.

-Your husband's foster brother, isn't he?
-That's right.
How much?
He brought this food, too.
Why?
You're wrong.

He's good, and there's no one else
around here like him.
Again.

Yes, he keeps his ace as a kicker,
and he draws to it every time.

-Three times.
-Mr. Kicker.
It's a game of chance, boys.
We'll play again sometime.

-I ran your errand.
-Thanks, Owen.
It's paid for like you pay for a coat.
I appreciate it.
It isn't the first time you saved my hide.
Why don't you grow up, boy?
Look, it happens.
I sleep well.
Your wife was there.
Does she have any idea?
Mm-mm.
It happened before I met Jen.

Even so, she wouldn't understand it,
you know what she's like.
Why should I know what she's like?
That's right, you don't.
She's what all the others weren't.
She's everything I ever wanted for myself.

It's been a long time,
let's get back to the ranch.
Stop right there, Daybright.
You, move away.
You brought Lily $500.
That's right.
Doesn't she need it?
Not that kind.

That wasn't grub money,
it was get-out-of-town money.
I'll ask you one time.
Was it yours?

Point that gun to the floor, Son,
and turn around.
They'll be other times.

You're a conclusion jumper,
and I don't like them.

-Quit it, Owen.
-I'll handle this myself, Con.
Not as long as I'm the sheriff.
All right, Con.
You've scared me twice tonight.
Next time you point a gun at me, shoot it.
Well, welcome home, boys.

-How are you, Arch?
-You look fit, Son.

-How are you, Owen?
-Good.

-How's the leg?
-It's got the misery.
Same as every winter for 20 years.

-Evening, boys.
-Hello, Mr. Willoughby.

I thought you might want
some hot coffee, Arch.
Well, thank you, Mr. Willoughby.
Same old dishwater?

-You don't want any, huh?
-Oh, no, I was just kidding.

-Then watch your language.
-How's the bad stomach?

Owen, some days I doubt
if I'll make it to sundown.

Why don't you stop
eating your own cooking?
Oh, I'm stuck here, I can't help it.
Arch, these cigars aren't from Pittsburgh.
Kansas City.
Hmm.
The place sure is going downhill fast.
How'd it go?
Ask the foreman.
I just took orders.
You got a wife waiting for you.
I hadn't forgotten.
I'll look in on her.

-Goodnight.
-Goodnight, Son.
Goodnight, Lee.
The boy looks trim.
Nobody could've worked harder this winter.
He's got a lot to make up for.
He'll come around.
Maybe Jen has something to do with it.
Anyway, he can handle it alone now.

Well,
It sounds like you're giving notice, Owen.
Lee's married now.
Jen's a fine daughter for you.
I'm just crowding the place.

-Oh, if you're not comfortable here…
-I'm not forgetting, Arch.

You've done all you could
to make me belong.

When you picked me up,
I was just a stray orphan,

foul-mouthed and flea-bitten,
15 years ago.
It's been a long time, a good time.
Now It's time for me to go.
You really mean it.

Well, I want to push on
and try my own wings.
Owen…
How do I say this?
When I took you, it was for Lee.

I couldn't get around outside
and raise my own boy,
so I picked you to do it for me.

What I didn't know then
was that I needed you, too.
I need you now.
All right, Arch.
I was hinting at you for a raise, anyhow.

-Goodnight.
-Goodnight.
Jen, will you hurry up and come on out?

I don't know why, all of a sudden,
you can't get dressed in front of me.
I'll be two more minutes, Lee.
On top of all winter, that's a long time.
I know that better than you.
You mean you've missed me?
Of course.
You're beautiful.
Do you think so, Lee?
Do you really mean it?

The first time I saw you,
you were wearing a pair of split britches.
You helped me come out of the backcountry.
You and Arch.

This is the second Sunday dress
I ever owned, Lee.

The first one I wore
to my mother's funeral.

Then I used it to bury my father,
then I burned it.
Now you're a lady of fashion, huh?

Well, that's what it says
in Godey's Lady's Book.

I haven't done
many smart things in my life,
but marrying you is one of them.
We'll be happy, Lee.
Nothing can stop us, honey.
Check in to the last call!
Where have you been?

-Morning, Mr. Willoughby.
-Morning, Owen.
Nice to see a real man back again.
Well, thanks, Mr. Willoughby.
Good morning, real man.
That nasty old noise woke you up,

or were you waiting for the sun
to hit your dimpled cheeks?

You Sunday men
haven't lost any sleep in so long
you've forgotten what you go to bed for.
Mr. Willoughby's buttering the foreman.
All right, all right, I slept late.

Why is it that when a man's out
on the range alone and eating his cooking,
he wishes to get up for breakfast?

Because when he's home
he lies there and has to figure out

if it's worth
the bellyache getting up for it.

You haven't done the contract
for the South, Esterly.

Anytime my cooking gets so bad
that you got to go hungry,

Arch will give you time before you know
what gave you the miseries.

-That's telling him, Mr. Willoughby.
-No offense, sir.

-Mr. Willoughby accepts your apology.
-I do.
There are no hard feelings.

-How about another cup of coffee?
-Sure.
I have to move you, Sheriff.

-Taking the census again?
-Yes.
I like to see who comes and who goes.
Hello, Hub.
I got your letter a week ago.
You're an uncle.
How's Lily?
She's doing all right.
Who's that?
The law.
Brothers, aren't you?
I'll kill a man before I leave here.
Anybody special, or would I do?

I don't know the man yet, but I will,
keep an eye on me.
The name's Fasken.

-Where are the horses?
-Behind the depot.
Fasken boys were looking for Lily.

They heard she'd been taken in
and given a home

by a widow named Mrs. Burke,
who owned a ranch nearby.

We're looking for Lily,
we're her brothers.
I didn't know Lily had this much family.
She never said a word.

-Maybe she's ashamed of us.
-Not Lily.
She's not that kind.
She's in her room.

-I'll call her.
-Nevermind.

-Is this the room?
-Yes.
So you sent for him?
The reason's over there.
I didn't ask for you to come.

-I didn't ask for you to come, you hear?
-We're this kind of family.
We don't waste any love on each other.

We've fought amongst ourselves,
we've even shot at each other.
We got one tie.
We're blood relations.
Go away, Hub.
Go away.
Do you want to marry Owen Daybright, Lily?
I don't want him, and I don't want you.
I'll manage myself without any help.
Daybright knows something.

If he can't talk when I'm done with him,
he'll write the name with his feet.
Ride him!
Scratch him, boy.
Hey, Mr. Kicker, you dropped something.
What he needs now is that fourth ace.
That's no way to break a horse.

Get on him
and ride him like you were taught.
Ride him, boy, ride him!
Hold him!
There you go.
Did you have to use that whip?
Owen's touchy.
Stop being such a farmer.
A good whipping never hurts any filly.
Come on.

-All those authorizations came in?
-All but Mrs. Burke's.
I'll ride over.

Cut me a horse, Hewie,
and one for yourself.

-Hi, Lily.
-Hello, Owen.
Hello, Hewie.
Good day, ma'am.
How do you feel?
I feel good.

-Why?
-I just wondered.
That's mighty good to hear.
Well, thank you.

Well, I just asked
because you look real fine, Lily.
Just fine.

-Had your breakfast?
-Mr. Willoughby's best.
I can outcook him with my two arms broken.
Business first, then we'll trade recipes.

Write a note authorizing us
to cut out your cattle at roundup
and bring them home.

I've been wondering
if I was being snubbed.

The only thing that can snub you
is a mountain.
I'll get paper and a pen.
Thanks, Owen, but I'm all right again.
You look fine, Lily.
Yes, that's what Hewie says.

I wish I could find the words to thank you
for bringing me the money, but I can't.
Well, don't try.
I hate to see you fronting for Lee.
Well, I'm thinking of Arch.
I know.

You go on standing in front of Lee,
protecting him,
letting his dirt rub off on you.
Maybe.

I'm thinking of Jen,
and all she's done for me.
That's why I can't tell.
We'll both keep it a secret.

-Lily, it isn't right…
-Owen.

I've been afraid of a lot of things
this past winter.

What people would say about me,
how I'd raise a baby,
and how I'd keep us both alive.

Well, now it's happened,
and I'm not afraid anymore.

I'm not glad it happened,
I was wrong, and I know that.
I'm just not afraid of living anymore.
Is Daybright here?
In the house.
Start walking to that shed over there.
Why?

You won't get hurt
if you don't break for the house.
Go on.
What is this?
You bought your ticket, you'll see.
Sit down.

Goodbye, ladies,
see you after the roundup.
Daybright.
So you sent for big brother.

Why don't I remind myself
to pack a gun when I visit my neighbors?

-That money was yours, Daybright.
-Oh, it was, huh?
That baby will need a name…
Yours.
Do you want another helping?
Come on, pull the trigger.

First, you shoot me,
then Hewie because he saw you.

Then, you'll have to shoot Mrs. Burke
and your sister because they'll see you.
Well, come on, pull the trigger.

-Quit it, Owen, he'll do it.
-I don't think he's got the guts.

-Put that down.
-That gun down, big brother.

You won't use it,
and I'll break your arm if you keep it!
Get up, Hub!
Dick, put that gun down.

Go ahead, cut down on her,
she's only your sister.
You have to kill somebody.

-Be careful who you poke in the belly.
-Hewie, that's enough.

-Whatever you say, Lily.
-All right, Hub, this is still our dance.
No, Owen.

Haven't I made enough trouble
for myself and my baby?
You want to add murder, too?
Owen, take them to the sheriff.

If you need someone
to sign the complaint, I'll do it.
All right, Lily, you've got the right.
Come on.
Go on.
I hear the Lazy W is for sale.

-How much?
-They're asking $35,000 cash for it.
That reminds me you owe me some money.
I generally do, Arch.

Joe Benson told me yesterday at the bank
that you were overdrawn.

Don't worry,
the old man covered it for you.

Still trying to fill
those inside straights?

-I always forget what you told me.
-Hey, have you been spending our money?
You know that's a joint account.
How much did he draw?
He said you drew it in gold.
Makes a nice clink in the pocket at that.

I'll see you later,
I must get ready for work.
Yes.
Is there some cream there, Jen?
Excuse me.

You don't believe
that story about the 500, do you?
No, I don't.

Honey, there are certain things
that you've to understand.

I don't like Arch knowing
everything that's going on.
Yes.

I can understand
your not wanting him to know.
That $500 is a lot of money.

I didn't like taking it either,
but it was for a lady's honor.
Stop it, Lee, stop it.
I know all about you and Lily.
Oh, I know what you're thinking.
Oh, honey.
That $500 was to help Owen out.

I don't want Arch
or anybody else to know about it.

Now that the fat's in the fire,
I'll have to tell you the truth.
You see, Owen got in trouble with Lily,
and the least I could do to help him was…
You know how much I think of Owen.

The least I could do to help him
was to give him the money.
You're a liar.
You're a mean, contemptible liar.
Hey.
You're all alike.
You, Arch, and Lee.

-You could be a little clearer.
-You're all liars.
Well, I'm through, I'm leaving.

-Slow down to a walk.
-That $500 you gave Lily.

-I know where it came from.
-Wait a minute, Jen.
Protecting him again.
Fighting with Lily's brothers.

You knew all about her
and Lee from the start.

It's just a lot of talk,
I'd pay it no mind.
Owen, why can't you be your own man?
These misunderstandings happen.

All married people quarrel
once in a while, I guess.
I hate him.
Jen.
You and I are kind of in the same fix.
Arch is all the family we got.
With him, we belong to something.

Shouldn't we give him back
a little bit in return?
Owen, what can I do?
What can I do?
Stay around for Arch.
All right,
but all I'll do is stay.
Morning, Mr. Kicker.
Hey, Owen.
What fell on you?

A couple of hard cases,
brothers by the name of Fasken.
Fasken?
Two of them?
Lily's clan is gathering.
Do they know?
You're still alive.

-Do you think they'll find out?
-Well, not for a while.
Sheriff's got them locked up.

-How long?
-A week.
They'll try again.
Who'll tell them?
Well, Lily might.

She doesn't want to,
but they're kind of hard to handle.
Well, what do I do?
You wouldn't do it.
Let's see.
There's only one way.
Take Jen and get out.
Stay away from here, begin all over again

because you've worn this place out
and your friends with it.
Sure, it's either that or get shot.
With me gone, the ranch is yours.
Nobody can stop you from thinking that,
but don't say it to me.
All right.
Hurt you?

I won't tell you,
you'll belt me once too often.

Now, you boys are going
out on a big roundup.

If you ride with a short
or underfed string,
you might as well be afoot.
Here's a horse you can have cheap.
A real Saturday afternoon bargain.
Sound of limb and body.

Rune, he's been burned so often
he looks like a brand book.
Just give me an offer.

I make out about 12 brands,
what do you say, Lee?

-I'd say a good round dozen.
-That means 12 unhappy customers.
No, Rune, I pass.
All right, anybody else?
Take him away.
Put him out to grass.

-Let's see the next.
-All right.

I got the best car horses
on this side of KC.
I got a pedigree that comes with this one.
Name your price.

Well, this looks more like it,
let me check him.
Open the gates, boys.

-Good horse, Rune.
-The only trouble is he's a whistler.
He leaks air.
You call that a leak?

Owen, you know better than to ride a horse
that way through town on Saturday.

That team at Wilfonts
took after you and almost ran away.

Don't blame me, blame the horse.
He whistles, and everything follows.
Hey, hold on, I'm not though yet.
You sure are.
Can't you hold your breath for a minute?
Put him away.

I wonder if the Fasken boys
are comfortable?
Who cares?
Let's look into them.
Pick me up later at the saloon.
Oh, Owen.
How are things?

-Quiet, Con.
-Getting ready for the roundup.

-Tough job.
-How'd you like to sign on?

-Thirty a month and meals.
-Oh, not me.
I sleep in a soft bed every night.
Help you?
I'm bringing the Faskens some cookies.

You better push them
into their cage with a stick.
They're a troublesome pair.
Want inside?
It might be catching.

-I understand the judge gave you a week.
-Judge?
A stinking justice of the peace.

Maybe next time
we can arrange a real judge.
Claw hammer coat and all.
Next time will be different.
Look.
Lily's doing all right without you, boys.
Why don't you leave her alone?
I see no Mrs. in front of her name.
Well, that happens.
No to a sister of ours.

Act like jackasses,
you'll be treated like them.

When you get out, the sheriff will put you
on the train himself.

Show your faces after that,
and you'll be back here for six months.
You scare me.

Say the word,
and I'll order curtains for this place.

By the way,
I've decided to go on roundup with you.
Not so easy, Lee.

There are things and people
you can't run away from.

-I'll think about it when I return.
-Think about it now.
Hold it.
There's a Cheyenne in that tree.
Got him.
That thing jumped into your hand.

-How'd you get it so fast?
-Practice, Son.

-You ought to try it.
-I haven't got the time.
Lee, the old Cheyenne camp.

Yes, remember the night
we rolled the rocks down on them?

I remember when Arch caught us
and the licking we got.

-I'd sooner been scalped by the Cheyennes.
-A few fool kids playing with Indians.
We had our time, didn't we?

-Good morning, Arch.
-Good morning, Lee.
Whew, I'm getting too fat.
Well, did you buy any horses yesterday?

Well, Obie Rune tried to push a wind broke
gelding off on us, but Owen caught him up.

-Obie never quits trying.
-Yes.

-Arch, you know I got thinking last night.
-Come on.
Tell me while we're walking.
Come on, walk with me.

What got me thinking was I saw a horse
at Rune's that I'd like to own,

and I began talking about the price
before I remember that I'm strapped.

-We always got money for a good horse.
-I don't care about the horse.
I probably own too many.

No, Arch, the point is that
a man my age with a wife,
with a father who owns half the county,

has to hold off buying a horse
because his wages won't let him afford it.
Oh, listen, Lee.

-You haven't been able to trust me.
-That's in the past, Arch.
You were right, but it's done.

-I've been a good hand this winter.
-Yes, you have.

Do you think I know the cattle business,
maybe not as good as you or Owen,
but well enough to make money at it.

If you need more money, you'll get it,
let me tell you…
When you came with Jen last fall,

I thought it was another foolishness
like all the others.
It wasn't.
Jen was something else, something right.

That's why I put you
on a top hand's wages, I'll raise them.
Oh, no, Arch, that's too easy.
Either I'm your son,

entitled to your trust with the ranch
or anything else, or I'm not.
It's one or the other.
What do you want?

I want to be part owner
of the ranch, Arch.
I want a share in it.
I'm married and settled down now.

Why, here's where I'll live
and raise my kids and die.

Here's where I'll help take over from you
when you've had enough of the business.
I'm not just camping here for wages.
I'm here to stay, Arch.
I'm your son.

I've been thinking about it too,
more than you.
A lot more than you.

You're my own blood,
a man has a debt to that.
Oh, you've got no debt to me, Arch.
Yes, it's an old one.
It began the day your mother died.

You got it coming to you, Lee,
for doing without her.
Well, we've managed, old timer.
I'm beginning to feel like one.

I'll go to town tomorrow
and draw the papers.
From now on, half the ranch is yours.
My half will go to Owen when I die.

-Hamilton.
-Flying H.

-Neely.
-Dog Iron.

-Sands.
-Lazy S Double O.

-Frank Peter.
-Box Pitchfork.
Frank Martin.
Let's see, Box F.

-Double F.
-That's right, Double F.

-Why do you carry them in your head?
-We got 40 different brands.

The biggest shuffle,
we'd have to move fast.

-Talk to you a minute, Owen?
-Sure, go ahead, Hewie.

I was back up in the mountains yesterday
looking for the last horses.
We tallied this morning, they're all in.

There's a small jag
of our cattle up there.

Brands are still haired over,
but I could tell they were ours.
I couldn't stop while turning the horses.

and by the time we got them
headed downhill, I was miles away.

-Do you want to pick them up today?
-I aimed to this morning.
They're gone.

They've probably been rounded up
by the other crew already.
No, they drove the other way.

-Did you trail them?
-As far as I could.

-Let's go try again, Hewie.
-I'll come with you.

Dust up and get my gun, Hewie,
and better get Owen's, too.
Take a look at this shoe.

You see the two caulks
on the inside and how it's built up?
This rider signed his name for us.
Two horses and four steers.
These tracks go straight for a while.
It got dark on me here, and I turned back.
A good place to cross if they went across.
You think like a cattle rustler.
Let's look on the other side.
Only one horse came out of the water here.
I was right, this horse is a decoy.

They either went up or downstream.
Hewie, you look below.
Yes.

There hasn't even been a horse
down this way.
There has been here,

and they were driving
some steers ahead of them.
Here's where they come out.

-That's Herb Backett's place.
-Yes.
Let's go and have a look.
Here he comes, two of them.
Are you looking for something?
Four steers.

They aren't in that watering trough,
their ears would stick up.
Come here, Herb.

Notice that caulk
and the built-up inside of that shoe.

-Who owns the horse that wears it?
-Never seen it before.
Here's another one.
It's fresh.
What about it, Herb?
What about what?

Whoever rode that horse
drove four of our steers here.

Look, if you see your steers here,
you can talk.
If not, I'm not accountable.
Get on your horse and leave.

I figure you butchered that beef
and buried the hides,
but I can't prove it.
I'm going to do the next best thing.

I'll show you what you buy into
every time I track our cattle here.

I heard
you were a pretty good saloon fighter.
